comments.commentBody:
Rima: Costco is very expensive, actually. A membership is $60. Thought you were unemployed again and broke? The food at Costco comes in restaurant-size containers -- that's their whole schtick (Sam's and BJs too). They get you to buy a gallon of mayonnaise instead of a pint, which is VERY wasteful. Unless you have six kids or a small business, I've got no idea what people are doing with this stuff.

Yes, the cost per ounce or serving may be less (not always!) but probably 50% of it goes to waste. The most expensive food you'll ever buy is the stuff you THROW OUT.

My wife and I have the executive membership, which is free once our annual rebate checks arrive each year.

I buy selectively from Costco, and waste little food. Their price on cheese, for example, is outstanding, and the cheese is often excellent varieties. Plus, it keeps well. No waste.

Wild fish is another great value. It can be portioned and frozen until needed. No waste.

Many items that are out of season, like berries, are far less expensive than supermarkets, and we consume them within the week. No waste.

Olive oil and coconut oil can be 2-3 times cheaper, and is again of excellent quality. No waste. Same with butter.

Some staples we use often, like mushrooms, are half the price of supermarket comparable items, and will easily last a couple of weeks. No waste.

Non-food items like paper towels and toilet paper are good values, and will be used eventually.

I don't buy the waste argument, sorry. We waste very little overall.

Well-said. Costco has excellent pricing on high quality good stuffs. IMO, they are a great store for a family of four, which includes two growing boys -- who happen to have a very healthy appetite for fresh fruit.

Additionally, only the inexperienced shopper buys the huge tub of mayo / horrid processed food product.

I must be missing something here. I go to the market,and I see a whole section of fruits and vegetables. We buy out bread at Trader Joe's as I like the multi grain bread and wife likes whole whet, it does not seem to hurt us. We buy most of our meat at COSTCO, and I see no problem not buying processes foods.

If you let your kids sit around and play video games instead of getting out riding their bikes, playing in the park, or taking walks with them, they are going to eat junk food and get fat. If they like hamburgers, buy ground round, make your own with the same garnishes, and they will love them.

As a substitute for french fries, saute sliced new potatoes in some butter with onions. There are many regular foods that taste as good as processed foods, or better.

But you do have to educate people. People do not seem to be able to connect cost of a product with the cost of poor health from eating junk food. that is the problem.

Regulate these food companies, and you will get a backlash from those whose incomes depend on them, and from the business friendly politicians who will be lobbied by them.

You have to educate the buyers, and that has to start in grade school. I have never had a problem getting kids to eat grapes and cherries, or fresh corn among many foods.

From a Time magazine piece I recently reblogged:

"Blaming excess weight on people simply not changing their eating habits goes back thousands of years. Sloth and gluttony are two of the seven deadly sins, after all. But Ludwig and Dr. Mark L. Friedman of the Nutrition Science Initiative in San Diego, argue that this mindset disregards decades of research on the biological factors that control body weight. And they are not just talking about the role genetics play. They say we should stop viewing weight as something separate from other biological functions—like hormones and hunger and the effects of what foods we eat, not just how much of them.

What, then, is causing the obesity epidemic? The authors say it’s refined carbohydrates. Sugar and processed grains like white bread which have become ubiquitous in our diets, and one of the reasons refined carbs is the prime culprit is that we’ve spent far too long chastising fat. “We have to forget the low-fat paradigm,” says Dr. Ludwig. “Some high fat foods like avocado, nuts and olive oil are among the healthiest foods we could possibly eat.”"

http://www.rimaregas.com/2014/06/eat-less-exercise-more-isnt-the-answer-...

"this opera is supposed to be 'anti-Semetic'." No that is not what was written. Instead, what was written was "“while the opera itself is not anti-Semitic, there is a concern the opera could be used in foreign countries to stir up anti-Israel sentiments or as a vehicle to promote anti-Semitism.” Anti-Semitism IS increasing in Europe, especially in Belgium and France. If (and notice I say if because I have not heard the score) the position and history of the Palestinians in the opera is portrayed as simple mindedly as is often portrayed  in the media and the blogosphere: "my land was stolen, Gaza is a concentration camp, Israel is an apartheid state, etc." without historical context and with distortion of the meaning of words, which for some excuses any and all actions of the Palestinians, then yes the opera could further incite anti-Semitism in regions, especially Europe, outside the middle east.   Besides, while I realize that the experience might not be the same, if you really want to listen to/see the opera, you can buy a recording from Amazon.

Pathetic, really. And nowhere in the article does Mr. Cooper say why or how this opera is supposed to be "anti-Semitic." Instead, he just repeats the charge, and lets this serious accusation float out there. Mr. Gelb should have taken pointers from the Opera Theater of St. Louis, but instead, this is another sign of the ongoing crisis at the Metropolitan Opera. And speaking of proven anti-Semites, why are any of Richard Wagner's operas ever performed there?
PLEASE impeach now. We could use the help motivating Obama supporters to turn out at the polls in November.
To Faceless Critic: Impeachment charge;Presidenting While Black.
Presidenting while black.

This is why the president doesn't want to tell congress what's happening, as with the 30-day notice on Sgt. Bergdahl; they politicize everything as they constantly seek to discredit him. They cannot be trusted. The more sensitive the matter, the less you can rely on them to do the right thing for our nation. I think the nation is beginning to get a very clear picture that they're number on priority is hurting President Obama, even if it means hurting our nation.

Corporations that make products get higher profits by expanding their market.  "Expanding" the food eaters is exactly what economics would predict.  The more you weigh, the more you need to eat to stop being hungry and maintain that weight.  It's just one more of what economists call "externalities."  The solution cannot be either to yell at either corporations for doing what they are created to do, or to human beings for responding to taste and to advertising campaigns.  We need social movements to change the incentive structure.  And we need a health care system that focuses on helping people eat better, rather than curing them of the diseases caused by obesity.

Dividing Iraq into three has an appeal which does not withstand closer examination.

First, the statelets would not likely all remain independent. They'd recombine with others on their borders.

We'd get a Kurdistan, and likely its wars.

We'd get a true Shiite Cresent, of Shiites recombining not just with Iran, but with the Shiites who are the whole population of the Saudi province that has all the Saudi oil, and with the 75% Shiites of Bahrain and its US Fleet Base and its central role in gas distribution, and with Syrian Shiites, and with Lebanese Shiites.

We'd get the Iraqi Sunni regions, stripped of oil and resources, lost in jihad over their impoverishment and disempowerment, jihadists aligned with Syrian, Lebanese, and Egyptian/Gazan jihadists.

Which brings us to the second problem: redrawing borders wouldn't just stop with redrawing Iraqi borders. Once it gets rolling, moving will have a power and logic of its own.

The Monarchs set up with the old borders are likely to be swept away. What would take their place? See Libya.

Moving people and redrawing borders would also likely reach people with disparate interests and ambitions regarding Israel. Whatever happened, it would be long and ugly war. It is impossible to imagine such turbulence leaving a peaceful eddy around Israel.

Who would gain? "The best lack all conviction, while the worst/Are full of passionate intensity." It wouldn't be the best.

tiredOignorance said: "When you have an enemy combatant (alleged) who waged war on the USA and was a part of a fighting force, an army, what "law" has he broken?"

A US consulate (anywhere in the world) is US territory.

If you commit a crime under US law on US territory, the US Government can try you.

Last time I looked, killing people was a crime on US territory. Committing arson is also a crime. Firing weapons is probably also a crime. You personal status, civilian or military (except maybe if you have diplomatic immunity) is not an issue. Doing the crime on US territory is the issue.

Is that simple enough for you? Or should we go over that again?
"Bring it on!"
Brilliant!
I'd like to know when Representative Issa is going to investigate the car alarms that wake me up in the middle of the night.

When Whitey Bulger was captured, that event was presented as a victory for law enforcement. The publicity and official self-congratulations did not keep him from being convicted and being sentenced to two life terms.

When Obama hadn't caught this guy you called him incompetent.

Now he's caught the guy, and you call him incompetent.

Do you see any problem here?
Let's all stop calling it "sectarian" violence; it's nothing but the oldest human motivation on earth: tribal religious wars going back thousands of years.

Not predicable, more like political; just look at the history from day one with
all the hoopla about "HOPE AND CHANGE"; there is hope and change , unfortunately, it is in the wrong direction caused by BOTH sides of the AISLE who seem more bent on bickering and not doing their job for which they were ELECTED for;, in my opinion;

Funny isn't it that the new media was able to interview a lot of the murdering terrorists that attacked our consulate and killed those Americans in Benghazi, but Obama, with all the resource of the U.S. at his disposal, couldn't manage to find 1 of these terrorists until the rest  of the Middle East has burst into flames, making him look like a total INCOMPETENT.  Then suddenly up pops one of these guys?   Obama is so predictable!

As the attack in Benghazi was unfolding a few hours later, Mr. Abu Khattala told fellow Islamist fighters and others that the assault was retaliation for the same insulting video, according to people who heard him.

The population of Iran was about 75 Million in 1911 according to Wikipedia, NOT 36 Million as you stated.

The literacy rate was 80% in 2007,[10][11][12] and 85% in 2008.

Thank you for remarking: "A peaceful Syria is easy too. We join forces with Assad and defeat the rebels and tell the Saudis to stop supplying them or else. Surely Assad will introduce a modicum of federalism for that."
The U.S. position on Syria has consistently and absolutely for regime change there.

Shouldn't Pres. Obama be asked why he is doing the bidding of PNAC, just like his predecessors since 1997 ?
And the neo-cons, like who founded PNAC, should be asked why they still want any of these regime changes when they just cause hundreds of thousands killed, millions of refugees, endless suffering, and the possible rise of a new caliphate. And wouldn't that threaten Israel even worse ?
And ask Israel why it doesn't care any more than Britain, or the U.S., how much terrible damage these wars have been doing.
We know Israel inflicts horrendous damage, like it did to the Gaza Strip in recent years, and how it destroys villages and olive groves and anything else whenever it chooses to.

I noted you gave a very incorrect figure for Iran's population. It was around 75 Million in 2011. You implied its recent population was only half that: 36 Million.

At least Friedman did not call Israel an island of decency. The place to begin is to show we want peace. Obama should tell Netanyahu that Kerry is right about apartheid, that unless it is changed immediately, we will go to the UN and call for South Africa-like sanctions. That will change policy in five minutes.

Friedman says that we should concentrate on small countries that are no problem and forget all problems. If that is it, he should retire. Sunni land is no problem at all.Turkey has 76 million people, Iran has 36 million. We should return to the 1000-year old practice of having the north the protectorate of Constantinople and the south of the Persians.

The Turks will ensure the Sunnis are governed by moderates and will impose peace in Kirkuk. The South will be governed by Al Sadr, but that was the predicted result of the Bush-Tom Friedman policy in 2003. (Tom was writing that Iraq was secular.) A reason to have immediate peace in Israel is for Jerusalem to be a model of a two-state capital for Baghdad.

A peaceful Syria is easy too. We join forces with Assad and defeat the rebels and tell the Saudis to stop supplying them or else. Surely Assad will introduce a modicum of federalism for that.

And, of course, let Iran be nuclear capable like Sweden and Japan without an immediate bomb and end sanctions. Iran needs to counterbalance Pakistan in the Afghanistan is certain to disintegrate with the Farshi endangered. It should control Al Sadr for that.

Well, in America wages for STEM workers are relatively low. Even for engineering. That suggests that American companies do not have a problem finding enough of them to meet their needs.

"...and we have a welfare system that pays the poor to have more children they cannot afford." Flat out wrong. Clinton disembowelled the welfare system. That's one of the reasons so many have suffered so badly. That's why so many need food stamps and the other support that is no longer available.

The liverals I know do not believe resources are endless. They are well aware that scarce resources command a higher price than abundant resources. What does that have to do with the price of labor? Are you willing to say that there are more workers available that are wanted? Marx pointed out that to keep the returns on capital rising Capitilism requires a massive reserve army of unemployed on the verge of starvation. Samuel Insull said, "The greatest tool I know of for increasing labor efficiency is a long line of men waiting at the gate."
Or, perhaps we shouldn't have ever invaded Iraq.
Why do you think that the FBI can't arrest people outside the US?

Stu Freeman, I think you have to realize that you are reading a column by someone who wrote in 2004 that he has "no problems with a war for oil."  His sensibilities will differ from those of decent humans.

How refreshing to hear a comment about our Saudi friends, the likely funders of the al Qaeda splinter group, ISIS.  It has been Sunnis funded by Saudis and other Gulf States who are terrorizing the West.  Clarity can have such a positive influence in creating a national policy.  The narrative in America must include the role of the Saudis in 9/11 and shape a crucial rejection of the oil addiction that enlivens this struggle in the Middle East.

Steve Ky.: If they have space, money, a "Caliphate" and a population to terrorize with Shariah law they'll have no reason to bother with infidels like us.  Provided, of course, that we don't bother with them.

I see no reason to believe that a "Sunnistan" composed of contiguous Sunni-dominated regions of Iraq and Syria would constitute a threat to the U.S.- unless we followed our usual instincts of meddling in matters that need not concern us. The Sunni insurgents have no affection for "Crusaders" or "Zionists" or for the West in general but they reserve their deepest animosity for the Shiite "apostates" with whom they've had to share a neighborhood for the past 15 Centuries. There were precious few attacks leveled by these people against the U.S. until Bush I stationed American forces on the holy soil of Saudi Arabia during and following the first Gulf War.  Our "friends" in the Saudi royal family proceeded to buy off bin-Laden and the rest by subsidizing al-Qaeda and financing Wahhabi madrassas in Pakistan and elsewhere.  At no point have they threatened to turn off the spigots if the insurgents were to attack their own American benefactors. I continue to believe that the extremists would happily stick to their own part of the world if only we would stick to ours (or, in any case, stop pushing our own traditions and values upon people who have no use for them). Insofar as the Sunnis and the Shiites and the Arabs and the "Persians" are concerned, we have absolutely no reason to choose amongst them; doing so would only have the effect of placing American civilians in danger both here and abroad.

"You can run but you can't hide."
President Bush said it. President Obama made it true.

The reading of the Miranda warning may be delayed, according to this article, to get further information on terrorist activities. He does not have to cooperate with interrogators and probably won't. Any information he does give prior to being read Miranda cannot be used against him at trial. He was apprehended after being indicted -- he is not just a suspect.  It is likely that he would be denied bail since he is a flight risk, to say the least.
This baffles me. "Too little and  way too late"...for what?

I am dismayed that in responding to this article this evening it has just been reported on the internet that our President has decided to send troops to Iraq under the auspices of protecting members of our embassy, I have supported our President in all manners large and small but I feel that this is revisiting a situation that we should never have been involved in to begin with and under no circumstances should we send one more young person to die for the problems of the middle east. Close the embassy and bring our people home. Involving  Iran in the mix might have been beneficial in bringing some semblance of peace to the region; apparently President Obama has been sufficiently pressured by Israel to forgo  that option. June sixteenth may go down as the day we were again caught up in the quagmire of the middle east, lets hope not.The American people are sick of this Mr. President bring the troops home to secure our own borders and rebuild America, look around at the millions of Americans whose lives have been ruined in the past dozen years, our country is falling down around our ears as we sit here and watch, get rid of the special interest groups that are destroying our nation. We are running out of time Mr. President, we need you and will support you, we know you want to do the right thing and bring America back.

It's just plain scary.  Law enforcement must be held to the same standard as civilians, with the same penalties.  Thugs in uniform must be purged.  Too often when one of them gets accused they close ranks very much like gang members.

That's certainly part of the problem.  But there are plenty of false accusations on all sides.  Supervisors must do a better job; they get the higher pay but they don't always earn it.  Some settlements should be paid by the cities but certainly not every time.

That's kind of like asking "Just a simple 'yes' or 'no' Mr. Smith, do you still beat your wife?"
But to answer your question, as someone who identifies as LGBT, I imagine I'd be intrigued, offended, provoked, hopefully moved, transported (if it was a successful opera), …
Those subjects should no more be off limits than that of The Death of Klinghofer.
